sect2.title: TAXONOMY, AND DESCRIPTION OF THE GENUS
sect2.para: Bartonella (previously named Bartonia, Rochalimaea, and Grahamella) species are fastidious, Gram-negative, coccobacillary or bacillary, small (~0.2 to 0.6 μm by 0.5 to 2.0 μm), arthropod-borne bacteria that evolved from free-living organisms and insect gut symbionts (1) (Fig. 1). They constitute the sole member genus of the family Bartonellaceae, classified within the Proteobacteria in the alpha-2 subgroup of the class Alphaproteobacteria and the order Hyphomicrobiales (previously named Rhizobiales). Most genus members are facultatively intracellular bacteria that parasitize erythrocytes, endothelial cells, and/or sometimes other mammalian host cells, causing persistent bacteremic infections and illnesses. All known Bartonella species have small genomes, averaging 1.8 Mbp and ranging from 1.4 Mbp for Bartonella bacilliformis to 2.9 Mbp for B. apis (1–5).

The genusBartonella is named in honor of Dr. Alberto Leonardo Barton Thompson (1871 to 1950), a Peruvian physician who discovered B. bacilliformis, the causative agent of Carrion’s disease, in 1905. Currently, there are 37 fully characterized species and 3 subspecies with validly published names, including species formerly in the genera Bartonia, Rochalimaea, and Grahamella. There are an additional 40 Bartonella designations, 32 with Candidatus status (www.bacterio.net/bartonella.html#r) (Tables 1 and 2). Twenty species, 16 with validly published names, are associated or suspected to be associated with human diseases (Table 1) (6, 7). Bartonella species infect a variety of mammals, and their prevalence is greatest in warm and humid climates (8). Members of this genus can be categorized into 3 groups: (i) human-specific species, (ii) zoonotic species, and (iii) animal-specific species (Tables 1 and 2). Phylogenetic analyses shed light on the evolutionary history of Bartonella. Bartonella apis, the honeybee gut symbiont, was shown to form a monophyletic clade with the human pathogen B. tamiae (9), which diverged before the eubartonellae were formed and separated into four deep-branching lineages (lineages 1 to 4). Species in lineage 1 infect humans, lineage 2 infects mainly ruminants, and lineages 3 and 4 infect a wide range of mammals (10). The three most extensively studied Bartonella species are B. bacilliformis, which is the type species, B. quintana, and B. henselae (11, 12).

B. bacilliformis, transmitted by sandflies of the genus Lutzomyia, is the etiologic agent of Carrion’s disease. The disease is characterized by two distinct phases, an acute febrile phase with hemolytic bacteremia, known as Oroya fever, and a chronic vasoproliferative form with cutaneous nodular vascular eruptions, known as verruga peruana (bloody warts). Until 1885, these two clinical entities were recognized as two distinct diseases. In 1885, Daniel Alcides Carrión, a Peruvian medical student, hypothesized that these two clinical entities are caused by the same etiologic agent. He therefore inoculated himself with blood aspirated from a verruga, and eventually developed Oroya fever and died after 21 days, proving his hypothesis (13). B. ancashensis is another species recently associated with verruga peruana-like clinical manifestations (6).

B. quintana, transmitted mainly by the body louse Pediculus humanus, is the agent of trench fever, which caused severe morbidity in hundreds of thousands of soldiers during the First and Second World Wars. B. quintana is also a cause of bacillary angiomatosis, characterized by vascular proliferative lesions in immunocompromised individuals, culture-negative endocarditis, bacteremia in homeless persons and persons with alcoholism (14–17).

B. henselae is the etiologic agent of cat scratch disease (CSD), a common, usually self-limited, zoonotic disease that may affect various organs in its atypical form and also a cause of endocarditis and bacillary angiomatosis in humans (6, 14, 18, 19).

This chapter focuses on the epidemiology, microbiology, clinical manifestations, and diagnosis of the three most commonBartonella spp. Other Bartonella spp., rarely reported as human pathogens, are noted in specific sections below.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Bartonella spp. are primarily infectious agents of nonhuman mammals, both domestic and wild, typically transmitted by arthropod vectors, such as fleas, sand flies, body lice, and potentially ticks, biting flies, and keds (wingless flies). Direct transmission from mammalian hosts also occurs, such as in CSD. Humans are incidental hosts for most Bartonella species, with the exceptions of B. quintana and B. bacilliformis, which are not considered zoonotic agents. Most species, such as B. quintana and B. henselae, have a worldwide distribution. A few species are geographically restricted, such as B. bacilliformis, which is found primarily at specific altitudes in the Andes Mountains of South America due to the limited distribution of its sandfly vector, Lutzomyia verrucarum (3, 4, 7, 20). Table 1 presents the Bartonella spp. and subspecies involved in human diseases, their reservoir hosts and vectors or potential vectors, together with the major disease manifestations in humans. Table 2 presents Bartonella spp. with standing in nomenclature that are not considered human pathogens. For other Bartonella species without standing in nomenclature, the reader is referred to www.bacterio.net/bartonella.html#r.

sect1.title: Cat Scratch Disease
sect1.para: The association between regional lymphadenopathy and cat contact has been known for more than a century; however, CSD was recognized as a syndrome by Debré et al. only in 1950 (21), long before B. henselae was identified as the principal causative agent. Other Bartonella spp. (B. clarridgeiae, B. quintana, and B. grahamii) and Afipia felis have been rarely associated with CSD (22–24). CSD is the most common Bartonella-associated disease among humans. Two retrospective studies in the United States, one of them among patients younger than 65 years of age, have estimated an annual incidence of 4.5 to 9.3 outpatient diagnoses/100,000 population and 0.19 to 0.80 inpatient admission/100,000 population (25, 26). Incidence of CSD is highest among those who live in the southern United States (6.4 cases/100,000 population) and among children 5 to 9 years of age (9.4 cases/100,000 population) (26). Based on these estimates, 12,000 to 25,000 cases are diagnosed annually in the United States and approximately 5% to 10% of patients are hospitalized, although higher proportions of hospitalization may occur (25, 26; M. Giladi, unpublished data). CSD occurs worldwide, though it is more prevalent in warm and humid climates. In temperate climates, incidence peaks during fall and winter, contrary perhaps to expectations for arthropod-borne infections (27–29). Apparently, healthy bacteremic cats constitute the major reservoir of B. henselae. Cat fleas (Ctenocephalides felis) may be responsible for horizontal transmission from cat to cat (30, 31), but less so from cats to humans. CSD usually follows contact with cats (especially kittens), but other animals (e.g., dogs) have been implicated as possible reservoirs in rare instances. Intrafamilial clustering is rare, probably due to the inefficient cat-to-human transmission. Person-to-person transmission does not occur.

sect1.title: Trench Fever
sect1.para: Trench fever, also known as 5-day fever or quintan fever, is caused byB. quintana. It emerged for the first time as a febrile epidemic illness affecting soldiers in the trenches during World War I. In World War II, another trench fever epidemic occurred, though a less extensive one (32, 33). However, recent paleomicrobiological studies have provided evidence that B. quintana has been a causative agent of human infection for 4,000 years (34). The human body louse, Pediculus humanus, has been identified as the vector, and humans are the only known reservoir for human infections. Recently, macaques from China and Japan were also found to be natural hosts of B. quintana (35, 36). The finding that all sequence types from human strains of B. quintana clustered together and were clearly separated from the 3 lineages of cynomolgus, rhesus, and Japanese macaque strains, together with the lack of evidence for macaque-to-human transmission, supports an evolutionary perspective that B. quintana has coevolved with host species to form a host speciation pattern.

Since World War II, endemic and sporadic outbreaks of trench fever have been reported worldwide, mostly in Africa. Since the 1990s, sporadic outbreaks ofB. quintana infection primarily in the United States and France, known as urban or contemporary trench fever, have reemerged in homeless people with alcoholism and louse infestation and living in urban areas in the absence of HIV infection (16, 17, 37, 38).

sect1.title: Carrion’s Disease
sect1.para: Carrion’s disease, or South American bartonellosis, caused byB. bacilliformis, is endemic to the Andes valleys of Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia. Sporadic cases have been reported from Chile, Bolivia, and Guatemala (7, 39). The disease is transmitted by the phlebotomine sandfly Lutzomyia verrucarum, which is typically found ~500 to 3,200 m above sea level. Other Lutzomyia species have been associated with outbreaks in areas where the disease is not endemic (40, 41). Possible maternal-fetal transmission of B. bacilliformis and transmission by blood transfusion have been reported (42, 43). Humans are the only known reservoir of B. bacilliformis. Oroya fever occurs most frequently among young native populations and transient visitors who are immunologically naive to B. bacilliformis. In a prospective cohort investigation of 690 participants in a Peruvian community with endemic bartonellosis, the highest rate of infection was reported in children <5 years old, and there was a linear decrease in incidence with increasing age (40, 41). Sandfly control measures (e.g., insecticides) and personal protection measures may decrease the risk of infection.

sect2.title: PUBLIC HEALTH IMPLICATIONS OF BARTONELLA INFECTION IN DOGS, CATS, RODENTS, AND BATS
sect2.para: Companion animals and rodents live in close proximity to humans, which facilitates easy transmission ofBartonella spp., 17 of which are zoonotic, from carrier animals to susceptible people (Table 1). Cats serve as carriers of several Bartonella species. Prevalence in cats varies among cat populations, including those that live in homes and strays, depending on the weather and geographic location; rates of 0% were reported in cold regions like Norway and up to 68% in warm and humid climates like the Philippines (44). Three Bartonella spp., including B. henselae (the agent of CSD, endocarditis, and bacillary angiomatosis), B. clarridgeiae (the agent of a CSD-like disease), and B. koehlerae (a cause of endocarditis in humans and dogs), are detected in cats, which are considered their natural reservoir, with B. henselae being the most prevalent (20). Three additional species, including B. quintana (the agent of trench fever, endocarditis, and bacillary angiomatosis), B. bovis (nonpathogenic to humans, dogs, and cats), and B. vinsonii subsp. berkhoffii (an agent of endocarditis in humans, dogs, and cats), were reported to infect cats but are considered rare and incidental (45–47). Immunocompetent cats do not usually develop clinical signs but serve as healthy bacteremic reservoirs (48). Veterinarians do not recommend treatment for healthy carrier cats due to the low efficacy of antibacterial agents in eliminating infection and the frequent occurrence of antimicrobial-related adverse reactions in felines. Treatment for cats should be considered when they are in close contact with immunocompromised patients or patients at high risk for endocarditis (48).

Dogs can be infected with severalBartonella species, including B. vinsonii subsp. berkhoffii, B. rochalimae, B. henselae, B. clarridgeiae, B. washoensis, B. elizabethae, B. quintana, and B. koehlerae, all known to cause diseases in humans. Of these, B. vinsonii subsp. berkhoffii, B. rochalimae and B. henselae are the main Bartonella species known to infect canids, and all have been implicated in significant morbidity in humans and dogs (49).

Rodents are considered common reservoirs ofBartonella species. The prevalence of Bartonella infection in rodents can reach 90%, depending on geographic location (50). To date, more than 100 rodent species and their associated arthropods (mainly fleas) have been reported to harbor bartonellae (51, 52). About half of the Bartonella spp. identified to date are hosted by rodents (Tables 1 and 2). Many Bartonella spp. of rodent origin were associated with human illness, including B. elizabethae (53, 54), B. washoensis (55), B. vinsonii subsp. arupensis (56, 57), B. tamiae and B. tribocorum (58, 59), B. grahamii (23, 60), B. kosoyi (previously called Bartonella sp. Tel Aviv strain) (61, 62), and B. rochalimae (63) (Table 1). These reports of Bartonella spp. highlight the importance of rodents as a source of human bartonellosis. Further exploration of other rodent-associated Bartonella species as putative zoonotic agents is warranted.

In recent years, bats were acknowledged as important reservoirs ofBartonella spp. Bartonella prevalence ranges from 7% among Nycteridae to 54% in Miniopteridae (64). A bat-associated species named “Candidatus Bartonella mayotimonensis” was isolated from aortic valve tissue of a patient with endocarditis (65). Further exploration of bat-associated Bartonella, especially among insect-eating bats, is warranted.

Bartonella infection is recognized as an occupational hazard for companion animal veterinarians, veterinary technicians, farmers, and national park rangers and workers (66–68). High serological and molecular prevalence, as evidence of previous exposure to or infection with Bartonella spp. were found in companion animal veterinary personnel from Spain; many reported chronic or persistent nonspecific symptoms such as headache, insomnia, fatigue, and memory problems (68). In another study, Bartonella DNA was detected in 32 of 114 (28%) veterinary subjects attending a conference, including B. henselae in 15, B. vinsonii subsp. berkhoffii in seven, B. koehlerae in six, a “Candidatus Bartonella volans”-like (squirrel-associated) sequence in one, and one with unidentified species. Two subjects were coinfected with two Bartonella spp. About 70% of positive subjects experienced clinical symptoms, including headaches and irritability (67). These studies should alert veterinarians and associated staff about potential exposure to Bartonella spp. and prompt further studies to determine the extent of this phenomenon among animal workers.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Bartonella spp. inhabit the midgut of hematophagous arthropods. They are excreted in arthropod feces and transmitted to humans mainly by scratches (and possibly by bites), which disrupt the integrity of the host dermis, as occurs typically in CSD (69, 70). Transmission can also occur when the hematophagous arthropod takes a blood meal on mammals (31, 71) or through the saliva of B. henselae-infected cats (72).

sect1.title: Cat Scratch Disease
sect1.para: Usually a self-limited illness, CSD has two general clinical presentations. (i) Typical CSD is more common, occurring in approximately 90% of CSD patients, and is characterized by subacute regional lymphadenopathy/lymphadenitis. (ii) Extranodal CSD, also known as atypical CSD, is the collective designation for several syndromes and numerous extranodal manifestations involving various organs, with or without lymph node involvement (73–75). In immunocompetent individuals, whether in its typical or extranodal presentation, CSD usually resolves without sequelae; however, the role of antibiotic treatment remains questionable. Rare cases of ophthalmologic involvement, particularly vascular occlusion, neurological complications, and chronic arthropathy, may not completely resolve. After recovery, immunocompetent CSD patients develop lifelong immunity, and reinfection is essentially nonexistent. B. henselae endocarditis should not be considered part of CSD and is discussed separately.

sect1.title: Typical CSD
sect1.para: The primary inoculation lesion, a small (0.3- to 1-cm) painless erythematous papule or pustule, develops at the inoculation site in about one- to two-thirds of patients. Lymphadenopathy develops proximal to the inoculation site 1 to 3 weeks or longer after cat contact. The affected lymph nodes are usually painful, sometimes have overlying erythema, and suppurate in ~10% of cases. Axillary and/or epitrochlear nodes are most commonly involved, followed by head/neck nodes and inguinal nodes. Approximately 50% of patients have fever, malaise, and anorexia. A smaller proportion experience weight loss and night sweats, mimicking the presentation of lymphoma. Fever and other systemic symptoms usually resolve within 2 weeks; however, resolution of lymphadenopathy is slow and may span several months (73, 75). Results of blood count, routine chemistry panel, sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein are not specific and may be within the normal range.

sect2.title: Neurological Manifestations
sect2.para: Encephalopathy/encephalitis is the most commonly recognized neurologic manifestation associated with CSD, occurring in approximately 1 to 2% of all recognized CSD cases (76–80). It is unclear whether encephalopathy and other CSD neurological manifestations are the result of direct B. henselae invasion or host immune response. Persistent headache is a common complaint, but fever may be absent. Approximately half of patients develop seizures. Regional lymphadenopathy, if present, is an important clue for diagnosis. Although most patients fully recover within days, intellectual impairment, ataxia, and seizures can persist. Death is extremely rare (80). CSD encephalopathy remains predominantly a clinical diagnosis, confirmed mostly by antibody testing and occasionally by molecular tests when infected tissue (e.g., lymph node) is available. Laboratory findings in CSD encephalopathy are usually not specific. CSF measurements range from normal to elevated protein concentration and/or pleocytosis with lymphocytic predominance, without hypoglycorrhachia (77). CSF cultures typically yield no growth, and PCR is negative except in rare cases. Other CSD-associated neurological manifestations are uncommon, including involvement of isolated cranial nerves and peripheral nerves, polyneuropathy, transverse myelitis, cerebellitis, and vertebral osteomyelitis with neurological complications due to intraspinal extension (80).

sect2.title: Ophthalmological Manifestations
sect2.para: A host of ocular manifestations, including various forms of uveitis, neuroretinitis, inflammatory disc edema, retinal vessel occlusions, optic neuropathy, and vasculitis, are observed in approximately 4% of CSD patients (81–83). Neuroretinitis, the most characteristic ocular pathology in CSD, though not pathognomonic, is a vasculitic process within the optic nerve head coupled with secondary macular involvement. The typical clinical presentation of CSD neuroretinitis is that of painless decrease of visual acuity, sometimes preceded by fever or development of regional lymphadenopathy. Neuroretinitis has been reported in association with B. henselae bacteremia, aseptic meningitis, encephalopathy, and fever-of-unknown-origin (FUO) syndrome (84). Although the long-term prognosis is usually good, some individuals may develop mild postinfectious optic neuropathy, and a few may develop permanent visual disturbances, particularly scotomas, after retinal vessel occlusions (82, 84).

sect2.title: Musculoskeletal Manifestations
sect2.para: Musculoskeletal manifestations are often severe, with a protracted course, and may evolve into a chronic course. In a surveillance study in Israel, 10% of 913 patients with CSD had musculoskeletal manifestations with varying degrees of severity, particularly myalgia and arthritis/arthralgia. Tendinitis and osteomyelitis, including multifocal disease, were less frequent. Arthropathy was more common in females older than 20 years and was associated with erythema nodosum (76, 85).

sect2.title: CSD FUO
sect2.para: CSD should be considered in the initial evaluation of FUO in both children and adults (84, 86). A prospective analysis of 146 children with FUO found that CSD was diagnosed in 7 (5%) patients (87). CSD-associated FUO is proposed to be a unique syndrome which may be severe and debilitating, for which the most common presentations include hepatosplenic space-occupying lesions, abdominal/mediastinal lymphadenopathy, ocular disease, and multifocal osteomyelitis. Fever may be continuous or relapsing. CSD FUO syndrome often mimics malignancy, particularly lymphoma, and a significant number of patients undergo invasive procedures for ruling out malignancy (84).

sect2.title: Hepatosplenic Disease
sect2.para: Hepatosplenic disease (also called CSD hepatitis/splenitis or visceral organ disease) is an uncommon manifestation of CSD which affects both children and adults and may appear as part of the CSD FUO syndrome but can also occur in the absence of fever (88, 89). Many patients have no accompanying peripheral adenopathy. Ultrasonographic or computed tomography (CT) abdominal imaging demonstrates multiple hypodense lesions in the liver, spleen, or both. Despite the protracted course, complete recovery is the rule (84, 89).

sect2.title: Other Manifestations of Extranodal CSD
sect2.para: Parinaud’s oculoglandular syndrome (granulomatous conjunctivitis with ipsilateral preauricular lymphadenitis), previously considered a common manifestation of atypical CSD, is today considered uncommon (73, 76). Pneumonitis, vertebral and peripheral osteomyelitis including multifocal osteomyelitis, and erythema nodosum have been reported rarely. Other manifestations and syndromes have also been associated with CSD, including idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, Henoch-Schönlein purpura, myocarditis, and pleural effusion (73–75).

sect1.title: Trench Fever
sect1.para: “Classical” trench fever, as described in 1919, ranges from a mild febrile illness to a recurrent or protracted and debilitating disease. The incubation period ranges from 3 to 38 days with an average of 8 days (32, 33). A clinical study among volunteers inoculated with the organism formerly known as “Rickettsia quintana” reported an incubation range of 5 to 20 days (90). Fever is often periodic, though prolonged fever of several weeks is also known to occur. Other symptoms and signs include malaise, headache, back and shin pain, profuse sweating, shivering, myalgia, arthralgia, splenomegaly, nuchal rigidity, and occasionally maculopapular rash. When untreated, the disease usually lasts 4 to 6 weeks. Death is rare (32, 90).

The clinical spectrum ofB. quintana bacteremia in contemporary, urban trench fever among homeless immunocompetent people resembles classical trench fever and ranges from asymptomatic infection to a febrile illness with headache, severe leg pain, and thrombocytopenia. Endocarditis may develop in a significant number of patients and should be actively sought, particularly in the presence of high anti-B. quintana IgG antibody titers (16, 17).

sect1.title: Carrion’s Disease: Oroya Fever and Verruga Peruana
sect1.para: B. bacilliformis can cause two distinct clinical phases: an acute (hematogenic) phase, known as Oroya fever, characterized by fever and severe hemolytic anemia resulting from bacterial invasion and destruction of erythrocytes, and a late phase, in which the patient develops dermal lesions known as verruga peruana, or Peruvian warts (bloody warts). The incubation period is 3 weeks (range, 2 to 14 weeks) (39, 91). In its mild form, Oroya fever may present as a nonspecific, self-limited, bacteremic febrile illness without anemia that may go unrecognized until the eruption of verruga peruana lesions. The fact that only a small minority of patients with verruga peruana had a clear history of an acute febrile phase that had occurred months before the eruptions suggests that many patients in the bacteremic phase are asymptomatic (92). In the severe form of Oroya fever, patients may appear pale with jaundice, occasionally with vascular collapse and impaired consciousness (39, 91). Secondary infection with Salmonella (Typhi and non-Typhi serovars) is common, though other secondary infections have been reported, including Shigella dysenteriae, Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella spp., Enterobacter spp., Candida spp., toxoplasmosis reactivation, histoplasmosis, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, leptospirosis, and malaria (91).

Verruga peruana, the eruptive phase of Carrion’s disease, appears 2 to 8 weeks or longer after recovery from Oroya fever and may persist for months or years without antimicrobial treatment (93, 94). Miliary skin lesions are the most common and are often associated with pruritus; nodular lesions usually appear as subdermal nodules; mular lesions are typically highly vascular and tend to bleed and ulcerate (91). Histopathological examination of the verruga lesions shows proliferation of capillaries with hyperplasia of endothelial cells, similar to the findings described in cutaneous bacillary angiomatosis (95, 96).

sect1.title: Bartonella Endocarditis
sect1.para: Following Q fever,Bartonella spp. are the second most common cause of culture-negative endocarditis accounting for up to 28% of cases reported in European studies (45, 97, 98). However, overall, Bartonella endocarditis is rare. In a recent U.S. 8-year single-center study, 11 patients with Bartonella endocarditis were identified among a total of 1,308 cases of definite infective endocarditis (0.84%) (99). Most reported cases have been attributed to B. quintana, followed by B. henselae, while other Bartonella species have been rarely reported to cause endocarditis, including B. elizabethae (100), B. vinsonii subsp. berkhoffii (45, 46, 101), B. vinsonii subsp. arupensis (57), B. koehlerae (102), B. alsatica (45, 103), and “Candidatus Bartonella mayotimonensis” (65). B. quintana endocarditis is associated with chronic alcoholism, homelessness, and infestation with body lice, whereas people with B. henselae endocarditis more commonly have cat exposure and preexisting valvular heart disease (98, 104). Although data from North America are limited, Bartonella spp. are believed to be the most common cause of culture-negative endocarditis in the United States. Bartonella endocarditis typically presents with nonspecific symptoms, such as fever, fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats, that may last weeks to many months before a diagnosis is reached (99). Fever may be absent; 75% of patients undergo valvular surgery. Death has been reported in 12%. Echocardiography demonstrates vegetations in most patients. An increasing number of reports of Bartonella endocarditis mimicking systemic vasculitis have been published. A recent review of the literature identified 54 cases of Bartonella endocarditis-associated glomerulonephritis with 77% of cases presenting with positive anti-neutrophil cytoplasmatic antibody (ANCA) (99, 105, 106).

sect1.title: Bacillary Angiomatosis and Bacillary Peliosis
sect1.para: Bacillary angiomatosis (sometimes called bacillary epithelioid angiomatosis or epithelioid angiomatosis) is a rare disease affecting severely immunocompromised patients, primarily HIV-infected humans with CD4+ T cell counts of <100/μl but also other immunocompromised individuals such as solid-organ transplant recipients and patients undergoing chemotherapy treatment (15, 107, 108). Bacillary angiomatosis is characterized by neovascular proliferative lesions involving various organs. A recent study has demonstrated the presence of Bartonella angiogenic factor A in B. henselae, which activates the host vascular endothelial growth factor pathway to drive angiogenesis (109). B. henselae and B. quintana are considered the etiologic agents of bacillary angiomatosis. Both species cause cutaneous lesions; hepatosplenic lesions are caused only by B. henselae, and lymph node involvement is more common in patients infected with B. henselae, whereas subcutaneous and lytic bone lesions are more frequently associated with B. quintana. Bacillary angiomatosis has also been identified in other organs, including the brain, lungs, bowel, and uterus (110). Bacillary peliosis is a closely related angioproliferative disorder caused by B. henselae and involving primarily the liver but also the spleen and lymph nodes. Bacillary peliosis is characterized by blood-filled cystic structures whose size ranges from microscopic to several millimeters. Risk factors associated with B. henselae infection include contact with cats or cat fleas, while low income, homelessness, and body louse infestation are associated with B. quintana infection. Patients usually have constitutional symptoms, including prolonged fever, weight loss, and night sweats (15).

sect1.title: Bartonella Infections in Solid-Organ Transplant Recipients
sect1.para: Infections caused byBartonella spp. are uncommon among solid-organ transplant recipients but both clinicians and clinical microbiologists should be aware of their unique characteristics (108, 111). Contrary to AIDS patients, who may be infected with either B. henselae or B. quintana, solid-organ recipients are almost exclusively infected with the former, probably since the medical protocols required for organ transplantations do not permit donors with louse infestations, alcoholism, or homelessness, factors associated with B. quintana infection. B. henselae infection in solid-organ recipients is commonly associated with cat exposure, tends to be more severe and with prolonged fever (as long as 4 months) compared with that in immunocompetent patients, and more often involve various organs, including liver, spleen, bone, lung, and bone marrow (108). Bacillary angiomatosis and hepatosplenic peliosis involving various organs have been reported as well. Transplant recipients with Bartonella infection usually have positive serology for Bartonella, although some test negative initially and seroconvert on follow-up testing. PCR can identify B. henselae DNA in various specimens, including blood, lymph nodes, liver, bone, lung, and bone marrow (108). The overall prognosis is good, and most patients recover after institution of antimicrobial therapy.

sect2.title: SAMPLE COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE
sect2.para: The preanalytical phase for a properBartonella diagnosis, consisting of sample collection, transportation, and storage, depends on the diagnostic method used, the clinical presentation, and the Bartonella spp. suspected to be involved. For instance, in CSD, lymph node biopsies or pus aspirates, cutaneous primary lesion biopsy samples, or superficial mucosal swabs may be targets for culture; however, isolation yield is extremely low. In these cases, serology and nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) for detection of Bartonella are preferred (112). For atypical clinical manifestations of CSD, samples such as vitreous or cerebrospinal fluid can be used for Bartonella diagnosis using NAATs and complemented with serological assays (113, 114). For endocarditis, heart valves, either native or prosthetic, are the best samples for identification of the offending Bartonella spp. complemented with serological assays. For trench fever, blood samples can be collected using sterile anticoagulated tubes (and the Isolator lysis-centrifugation system, if available) and submitted for Bartonella detection. EDTA and heparinized tubes are widely used and maintain the viability of Bartonella spp. for weeks to months (115–117). Similarly, B. bacilliformis and B. ancashensis have been successfully isolated from blood samples of patients with Oroya fever and/or verruga peruana (118, 119). Notably, previous antibiotic therapy must be taken into consideration, since it may reduce the chances of Bartonella isolation (112).

Due to the slow-growing nature ofBartonella organisms, if culture is considered, special care must be taken to avoid contamination with environmental or skin-associated organisms, which usually include fast-growing bacteria and fungi. Thorough disinfection of the overlying skin before specimen collection is highly recommended, especially when animal samples are collected. If a tissue biopsy specimen is processed for culture, it is recommended to scrub the area with chlorhexidine gluconate solution followed by 70% ethanol and rinse a few times with sterile saline before taking the specimen to reduce the load of potential superficial contaminants (120).

Transportation of clinical samples must be as fast as possible, at 4°C, especially for culture. Tissue samples can be maintained in sterile saline solution during transportation. NAATs are preferred over culture. Blood samples can be collected using EDTA, or sodium citrate (110). When tissue specimens are not processed on the day of collection, they should be kept frozen (−20°C or −80°C).

sect1.title: Microscopy of Thin Blood Smears
sect1.para: Due to the hemotropism ofBartonella spp., blood samples are potentially an ideal target for microscopic examination. However, except for B. bacilliformis, for most Bartonella spp., the numbers of organisms per erythrocyte in vivo are too low to allow identification by light microscopy, and the proportion of colonized circulating erythrocytes also tends to be low (ca. 1 to 5%) (121, 122). Moreover, animal models show that Bartonella bacteremia can be cyclic, and therefore, periods of low-level bacteremia or its complete absence are frequent, leading to false-negative results (71, 123). It has been suggested that cyclic bacteremia may be linked to fever relapses in B. quintana infections (124). These factors limit the usefulness of microscopic evaluation of blood samples to identify Bartonella bacteremia. In contrast, identification of B. bacilliformis on Giemsa-stained thin blood smears is a simple and fast mode of diagnosing Oroya fever in areas of endemicity. Smears show typical single or multiple intraerythrocytic, red- or purple-staining rods or rounded bodies. Positive thin smears have been reported in 2 to 100% of erythrocytes (mean, 61%). The proportion of infected red blood cells (RBCs) does not predict outcome or response to therapy (7, 91).

sect1.title: Histopathology
sect1.para: Biopsy tissues are routinely processed in 10% neutral buffered formalin and embedded in paraffin. Although histopathology of CSD and bacillary angiomatosis is typical but not specific, it helps to narrow the differential diagnosis. Reactive follicular hyperplasia is seen in the early stages of CSD lymphadenopathy, followed by stellate suppurative granulomas with acellular necrotic centers and multiple stellate microabscesses near the subcapsule of lymph nodes. Silver-based stains, including Warthin-Starry and Steiner stains, are recommended for microscopic detection of organisms in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue sections, but such staining is difficult to perform, not highly specific, and relatively insensitive when lymph node biopsy specimens from CSD patients are examined. In patients with bacillary angiomatosis, a larger number of bacilli, some in clumps, can often be visualized by Warthin-Starry silver staining of tissues (Fig. 2) (125).

sect1.title: Antigen Detection
sect1.para: Immunostaining, either immunohistochemistry or immunofluorescence, and fluorescencein situ hybridization can identify Bartonella spp. in various clinical specimens with variable sensitivity (125–127). Since neither of these techniques is widely available, they are not routinely used in clinical microbiology laboratories for Bartonella diagnosis.

sect2.title: NUCLEIC ACID AMPLIFICATION TESTS
sect2.para: PCR has been applied for diagnosis ofBartonella infections, using various clinical specimens, different approaches and methods (including conventional, real-time and droplet digital PCR assays), and a number of genomic targets (128–132).

Conventional PCR assays were initially described for direct detection ofBartonella DNA from clinical samples (128, 129). Later, nested and real-time PCR assays were introduced to improve Bartonella diagnosis (130, 133). Considering the increasing number of novel Bartonella spp., DNA sequencing of PCR products is recommended to confirm Bartonella species identity when results are ambiguous or are not in accordance with the clinical presentation. Many conserved and housekeeping loci have been developed as targets for detection of Bartonella DNA, including the genes for citrate synthase (gltA), RNA polymerase β-subunit (rpoB), heat shock protein (groEL), riboflavin synthase (ribC), a cell division protein (ftsZ), and the 17-kDa antigen and the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region located between the 16S and 23S rRNA genes (131). The 16S rRNA gene was first used by Relman et al. in 1990 for the identification of the causative agent of bacillary angiomatosis. It is considered useful for detection of Bartonella but does not discriminate among all Bartonella species (128). When clinical samples are expected to have low Bartonella loads, methods to enrich for Bartonella DNA may be helpful (120).

The clinical sensitivity of the PCR assays varies among studies, ranging between 45% and 95%, because of either poor performance of the assays, types of clinical specimens used, or lack of consensus regarding a CSD case definition (129, 134–143). A recent retrospective study of 390 CSD patients and 482 PCR tests, using a national CSD registry in Israel and a uniform case definition, found that specimen type rather than PCR assay type had a major impact on the performance of molecular diagnosis of CSD. The highest PCR sensitivity was achieved with lymph node pus aspirates (96%), followed by primary lesions (88%), lymph node fine-needle aspirates (85%), lymph node biopsy specimens (73%), and formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded lymph nodes (59%) (144). It was hypothesized that the unexpected low sensitivity of the lymph node biopsy specimens was due to sampling errors or the presence of inhibitory factors (129, 134, 144). PCR performed on formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded lymph node biopsy specimens is notorious for low sensitivity, possibly due to the various steps of fixation and embedding of the tissues as well as deparaffinization, which are known to damage DNA (137, 145). It has also been postulated that because during the fine-needle aspiration process, the needle is inserted and withdrawn several times in different directions, cells from multiple locations within the lymph node are obtained, resulting in a higher sensitivity than with biopsy specimens. It should also be noted that Bartonella DNA can persist in tissues for long periods of time, even with appropriate treatment.

While real-time PCR is often the diagnostic assay of choice, it does not necessarily have a higher rate of detection ofB. henselae DNA from clinical CSD specimens compared to conventional PCR (144); 100% agreement between conventional and real-time PCR is reported (142). In contrast, the clinical sensitivity of nested real-time PCR was reported to be superior to that of nested conventional PCR, both targeting ribC for Bartonella detection in serum samples of Bartonella endocarditis patients (130). It should also be emphasized that in spite of the superb specificity (approaching 100%) and relatively high sensitivity, depending on the specimen type, CSD diagnostic PCR testing requires tissue samples that are not always available. Though readily available, blood specimens have unacceptably low PCR sensitivity for CSD diagnosis (146).

sect2.title: SEROLOGY
sect2.para: Although sometimes challenging to interpret, serological assays, both immunofluorescent antibody (IFA) test and enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for detection of anti–Bartonella antibodies are the mainstay of diagnosis for many Bartonella-associated diseases. However, serology has limitations, including frequent lack of anti-Bartonella IgM even in documented acute infection; variable sensitivity, ranging from lower than 50% to 95%; late seroconversion, 3 weeks or more after presentation; and cross reactivity between B. henselae, B. quintana, and other Bartonella sp. antibodies, as well as with serum of patients with Q fever or Chlamydia pneumoniae infections. Due to these limitations, the FDA has not cleared any serological assay for diagnosing Bartonella infection. A number of IFA assays and EIAs have been described, primarily for detection of anti-B. henselae and anti-B. quintana antibodies (19, 38, 147–156). In 1992, Regnery et al. described an IFA test for IgG (19). Since then, IFA testing has become the most commonly used diagnostic test for Bartonella infections, as either a homemade or commercial product, performed by the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the French National Reference Center for Rickettsial Diseases, among others (19, 45, 157). B. henselae and B. quintana bacteria cocultivated with Vero cells or a human endothelial cell line are utilized as antigens by the CDC and the French reference laboratory IFA assays, respectively. In both assays, with the exception of endocarditis, a fluorescent reaction at a >1:64 dilution is considered positive. The CDC assay was designed for IgG detection only, while the French IFA assay reports IgM results as well. For many EIAs, a result at a >1:100 dilution is considered positive. As with other serologies, seroconversion or a 4-fold increase strongly supports a diagnosis of active Bartonella infection (19, 149, 157, 158). In comparison with EIA, the IFA assay has several disadvantages: Preparation of antigen requires cultivation of Bartonella spp. in Vero cells or other cell lines. Attempts to use agar-derived antigens have resulted in autoagglutination of the Bartonella bacilli, which interferes with the IFA (19). In addition, IFA assays in general suffer from interobserver variation and are not suitable for automation or for screening large numbers of specimens. Earlier studies showing that EIA-based CSD serodiagnosis was inferior to that obtained with IFA assays were flawed by not providing sufficient data to evaluate the assay or to interpret sensitivity and specificity (139, 152, 159). Utilizing various antigens, more recent studies demonstrated better performance of EIAs for CSD diagnosis (149, 158, 160–163).

In studies where IFA assays were performed at the CDC by using the method of Regnery et al., sensitivity (84% to 95%) and specificity (94% to 98%) for detecting anti-B. henselae IgG were high (19, 147, 148). Results of the IFA test using various in-house and commercial assays were inconsistent and less satisfactory in studies performed in Europe (139, 155–157, 164). It has been suggested that high background seroprevalence of anti-B. henselae IgG in Europe due to exposure to non-B. henselae Bartonella spp. results in inferior performance of the IFA test compared with that in the United States; however, a direct large-scale comparison between populations from Europe and the United States has never been performed.

Serology is an important tool for diagnosis ofBartonella endocarditis. Both the IFA test and EIA demonstrated in two retrospective studies that anti-Bartonella IgG titers of >800 were recorded in 94% of patients with Bartonella endocarditis, while the remaining patients demonstrated lower titers (45, 165). However, both the IFA assay and EIA have similar limitations, which need to be recognized to avoid incorrect diagnosis, as follows.

listitem.para: IgG titers of <800 can represent rare cases ofB. henselae or B. quintana endocarditis but could also be attributed to endocarditis caused by non-quintana, non-henselae Bartonella spp., as demonstrated with B. koehlerae and B. alsatica endocarditis patients who had IgG titers of <800 when B. henselae or B. quintana antigens were used (45, 165).
Due to cross-reactivity betweenB. henselae and B. quintana, serology cannot discriminate between these two species, the most common etiologic agents of Bartonella endocarditis (165, 166).

Cross-reactivity betweenBartonella spp. and Coxiella burnetii is concerning since both are important etiologic agents of culture-negative endocarditis with similar clinical characteristics yet with dissimilar antimicrobial treatment recommendations (150, 165, 166). Approximately 40 to 50% of patients with chronic Q fever have antibodies which significantly react with B. henselae and/or B. quintana (150, 165). It should be noted that Bartonella-Coxiella cross-seroreactivity infrequently poses a clinical quandary, since in the majority of cases, titers of IgG against the true pathogen are several dilutions higher than those for the pathogen causing the false-positive serology, thus allowing the correct diagnosis to be made.

Cross-reactivity, mostly at low levels, is observed in cases ofChlamydia pneumoniae infections, a rare cause of endocarditis (38, 165); in infections with Brucella melitensis, a pathogen phylogenetically close to Bartonella; and in patients with culture-positive infective endocarditis, particularly cases caused by Enterococcus faecalis. Recent publications demonstrated serologic cross-reactivity in IFA assay or EIA between E. faecalis and Bartonella in endocarditis patients, as confirmed by Western blotting. However, cross-reactivity in patients with C. pneumoniae, brucellosis, and E. faecalis endocarditis was uncommon and always at low titers, supporting the use of high anti-Bartonella IgG titers for Bartonella endocarditis diagnosis (165, 167).

sect2.para: Although cross-adsorption studies and Western blot analyses assist in identification of the true culprit in cases with cross-reactivity and also increase diagnostic sensitivity, these assays are time-consuming and require appropriate equipment and expertise not currently available in most clinical microbiology laboratories (45, 150).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Bartonella culture isolation is the only method that can truly detect an active infection, but success rates are extremely low. It has been postulated that B. henselae is not viable in affected lymph nodes of most immunocompetent CSD patients and that the host’s immune response rather than direct invasion by B. henselae is responsible for lymphadenitis (168).

Bartonella spp. are slow-growing fastidious bacteria. Culture isolation requires enriched medium (e.g., medium supplemented with whole blood, hemin, hemoglobin, or serum) and long incubation periods with a humid atmosphere and 5% CO2, at 35 to 37°C, except for B. bacilliformis and B. clarridgeiae, which grow best at 25 to 30°C. A variety of agar base media have been used for the isolation of Bartonella, including Columbia, Brucella, brain heart infusion, and Trypticase soy media (all supplemented with 5% blood, usually from sheep or rabbit) and chocolate agar (Fig. 3; 169–171). Unlike with animal samples, primary isolation from clinical human samples requires longer incubation, up to 5 to 6 weeks, to be successful. The median incubation time to obtain sufficient growth of B. henselae from lymph nodes is 21 days (172). Bartonella spp. may also be isolated from cutaneous lesions of patients with bacillary angiomatosis (169), as well as from blood, liver, spleen, or cardiac valvular tissue, but sensitivity is poor.

Once evident, colonies grow slowly, producing small size changes over subsequent days (120). Subculturing isolated colonies usually requires shorter incubation periods, ranging from 4 to 10 days (fully grown colonies) at optimal temperatures when performed as soon as possible to preclude rapid loss of viability. Notably, it is recommended to seal the plates with semipermeable membranes (e.g., Parafilm or commercial cellulose shrink seals) to allow oxygen and carbon dioxide gas exchange, to retain a humid atmosphere, and to decrease contamination (120).

Certain culture pretreatments enhanceBartonella isolation. Cell lysis of blood samples with an Isolator lysis-centrifugation system and freeze-thawing techniques promote release of intraerythrocytic Bartonella (115, 172). These techniques are used for isolation of Bartonella spp. directly from blood followed by plating onto fresh (≤7 days after pouring) chocolate or heart infusion agars containing 5% fresh rabbit blood, in the absence of antibiotics. B. koehlerae is extremely fastidious, will not grow on heart infusion agar, and requires fresh chocolate agar plates (173). Commercial sheep or horse blood agar plates have also been used but are insensitive for primary isolation of Bartonella species. If a CO2 incubator is not available, incubation in candle jars or sealed gas-permeable plastic bags aids in preserving moisture and limiting contamination. Cultures in candle jars are optimally not checked until 1 week after inoculation and then are checked every 7 days thereafter, to avoid introducing contaminants and releasing humidity. Inoculation of Bartonella-infected blood into the broth of CO2 detection-based blood culture systems does not usually produce turbidity or convert enough oxidizable substrate to CO2 for detection. Thus, automated blood culture systems rarely detect Bartonella spp. from patient blood. Acridine orange staining of the blood culture bottle, with blind subculturing onto enriched medium if the acridine orange stain is positive, may be helpful, but this requires fluorescence microscopy (17). In addition, tissue and cells can be concentrated by centrifugation to increase the chances of isolation (31). Although initial cocultivation with an endothelial-cell monolayer improves isolation of Bartonella spp., this modality is not readily available in clinical laboratories.

figure.title: FIGURE 3 Three-week-old colonies form primary isolation of B. henselae strain Houston I from a bacteremic stray cat. Growth was first visualized after 10 days of incubation on a fresh chocolate agar plate incubated in a humid atmosphere at 36°C and 5% CO2. Colonies are of heterogeneous size (which might be interpreted by the microbiologist as a mixture of more than one strain), elevated, rough, gray, and deeply embedded in the chocolate agar.

sect2.para: To reduce overgrowth and the impact of contaminants, dilution of clinical samples (1:2 to 1:16) in liquid culture medium supplemented with 5% amphotericin B (to prevent fungal contamination), prior to seeding of a sample in an agar medium, increases isolation rates (174). Preincubation of samples in a liquid medium, prior to agar seeding, improves primary isolation as well (175, 176). Nevertheless, despite improvements in culturing Bartonella, the techniques are laborious, time-consuming, and insensitive for routine clinical diagnosis. A more in-depth discussion of culture-based and other diagnostic methods for the detection of Bartonella spp. can be found in the review by Gutiérrez et al. (120).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Because of the slow growth of these bacteria on agar plates, standard biochemical methods for identification are not useful for clinical diagnosis of infection. Identification ofBartonella isolates has mainly relied on the sequencing of conserved and housekeeping genes. Phenotypic characteristics of Bartonella growth include long incubation of 8 to 45 days before primary isolation. Colonies of B. henselae have two morphological types that can grow simultaneously from the primary culture: (i) irregular, raised, off-white, dry, rough (cauliflower-like) colonies that pit and adhere to the agar, and (ii) small, circular, tan, and moist colonies that are more easily scraped from the agar surface (Fig. 3). B. quintana colonies are usually smooth, flat, and shiny; they are more tan-colored than those of B. henselae and do not pit the agar (14, 110). Highly passaged and confluent B. quintana colonies can appear somewhat mucoid. B. clarridgeiae produces small, white, raised, indurated, and cohesive colonies, which can also appear to spread during primary isolation. Most Bartonella spp. appear uniformly smooth after repeated subcultures.

The bacilli are small (2 by 0.5 μm) and stain best with the Gimenez stain (14). With Gram staining, Bartonella species are weakly counterstained with safranin or basic fuchsin and appear as small, Gram-negative, slightly curved rods somewhat resembling Campylobacter, Helicobacter, or Haemophilus spp. Colony morphology, in conjunction with growth requiring more than 7 days of incubation, along with negative catalase and oxidase reactions, is often sufficient for preliminary identification. DNA amplification and sequencing are optimal for confirmation of the Bartonella genus and determination of species, and sometimes their strains. B. bacilliformis, B. clarridgeiae, B. rochalimae, B. ancashensis, B. melophagi, and B. schoenbuchensis are motile by means of unipolar flagella. B. henselae, alongside several other Bartonella species, has a twitching motility on wet mount, associated with the expression of trimeric autotransporter adhesins, as shown for B. henselae (177). Most Bartonella spp. are biochemically inert except for the production of peptidases. None of the commonly used commercially available bacterial identification systems, such as API (bioMérieux, Marcy-l’Étoile, France), Vitek-2 (bioMérieux), and several matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) instruments (e.g., Bruker Biotyper CA and Vitek MS), include default panels or profiles for Bartonella sp. identification. However, the potential role of MALDI-TOF MS as a diagnostic tool in the microbiology laboratory was shown in a study demonstrating identification and differentiation of 17 distinct Bartonella species (178). It is expected that the inclusion of Bartonella spp. mass spectrometry profiles in the commercially available MALDI-TOF systems would assist significantly in identification of these organisms.

Nucleic acid techniques are required for accurate species determination, strain determination within a given species, and genotyping. Methods include PCR, DNA hybridization, restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis and gene or whole-genome sequence analysis. PCR and sequencing of target genes, such asgltA, rpoB, the ITS region, 16S rRNA, groEL, and ribC, are the most widely used. La Scola and colleagues (131) set the baseline criteria for species identification of this genus. However, the extensive list of diverse Bartonella organisms in nature challenges these determinations when a single or a few genetic loci are used (61, 179). Moreover, the common finding of coinfection of animals by two or more Bartonella spp. limits direct identification without proper isolation (i.e., assurance of single clones). Recently, Kosoy et al. (5) provided a recommendation for consistent genotyping of Bartonella spp. Remarkably, in many cases complete species identification of novel Bartonella spp. requires whole-genome characterization (62).

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Molecular typing methods are useful for understanding the epidemiology ofBartonella infections, such as transmission of species from animals and arthropod reservoirs to humans, and for differentiating and characterizing novel species (5). A variety of typing methods have been described over the past 2 decades. The choice of typing method depends on the targeted species and whether the organisms are primarily recovered from humans, felines, or other nonhuman hosts. For example, human strains of B. henselae are more homogeneous than those of felines (180) and therefore require a more discriminating typing method. Given that there is variability in the frequency of genome rearrangements among species, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis is unreliable for epidemiological studies of B. quintana isolates (181), while other methods demonstrate better discriminatory power, including multilocus sequence typing (MLST), which incorporates nine genes (180, 182–184), ITS (16S-23S tRNA-Ala/tRNA-Ile intergenic spacer S1) sequence typing methods (185), and multispacer typing methods (181), with the last two reported to be most discriminatory (183, 185). B. vinsonii subsp. berkhoffii can be separated into four distinct genotypes based upon 16S-23S ITS sequences (186). In a study of Japanese cat and human isolates of B. henselae, the authors were able to classify strains belonging to MLST-1, the major B. henselae sequence type, into seven distinct genotypes, demonstrating significant genetic diversity within MLST-1 and linking genotypes among cats to human disease (184). Another study found that a multispacer typing method based on five noncoding segments performed on B. quintana isolates recovered from lice and humans enabled identification of four genotypes and that DNA rearrangement did not affect typeability, in contrast to pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (181). MLST for B. quintana, utilizing nine genetic loci, resolved 16 strains into seven sequence types, including uncultured strains identified by direct PCR from cardiac valve tissue (187). Most studies of typing methods are limited by small numbers, geographic boundaries, or target-specific animal hosts. A discussion of genotyping methods for diagnostic purposes is presented in a review by Kosoy et al. (5).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY AND SUSCEPTIBILITY TESTING
sect2.para: As facultative intracellular pathogens with a unique stealth infection strategy (124), Bartonella spp. present challenges for effective choices of treatment. The endothelium lining blood vessels, considered the primary niche of Bartonella spp., serves as a protective reservoir, leading to persistent infection and relapses. Technical obstacles extend to the clinical laboratory, particularly related to the fastidious and slow-growing nature of these organisms on traditional media. Neither the Clinical Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) nor the European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) has established guidelines, criteria, or clinical breakpoints for Bartonella antimicrobial susceptibly testing. Nevertheless, several studies, using different methodologies, antibiotics, and culture conditions in vitro, have attempted to determine MICs for Bartonella spp., which serve as an empiric baseline for drug choice (188–193). Many antibiotics tested in vitro have low MICs (<0.5 μg/ml). Accordingly, Bartonella spp. are consistently highly susceptible to doxycycline, macrolides, rifampin, and most beta-lactams. High susceptibility has been reported for gentamicin, with variable MICs for other aminoglycosides and inconsistent results for fluoroquinolones. Several studies describe various molecular mechanisms that could confer resistance to fluoroquinolones (194–196), but clear evidence of resistance developing in vivo after fluoroquinolone use is lacking. A study that evaluated the in vitro antibiotic susceptibility of human strains of B. bacilliformis reported low MICs of fluoroquinolones (197), whereas another study reported that B. bacilliformis possesses constitutive resistance to fluoroquinolones, which may be related to the presence of alanine at position 91 of DNA gyrase subunit A (GyrA) and position 85 of DNA topoisomerase IV subunit A (ParC) (194). The latter findings argue against current clinical guidelines that recommend ciprofloxacin to treat bartonellosis in some countries of the Andean area. Higher MICs are recorded for oxacillin, cephalothin, clindamycin, fosfomycin, colistin, and vancomycin when tested on various Bartonella spp. (190–194, 197). Gentamicin and streptomycin were the only antibiotics demonstrating bactericidal effects on B. henselae and B. quintana (198). These findings support the recommendation to add gentamicin to doxycycline for treatment of Bartonella bacteremia or endocarditis (199).

Commercial manufacturers offer microbiological inhibition tests [i.e., antibiotic gradient strips (e.g., Etest [AB Biodisk, Solna, Sweden]) with specification for use onBartonella spp. MICs determined by Etest correlate with standard agar dilution methods (191), supporting application in clinical laboratories. Notably, variability related to the medium employed for antibiotic susceptibility testing has been observed (188, 200). Mueller-Hinton and Columbia agar media supplemented with sheep whole blood or 1% hemoglobin and chocolate agar have been used for antibiotic susceptibility testing of Bartonella and demonstrated different results (191).

Despitein vitro testing data showing high susceptibilities of Bartonella spp. to many antibiotics, other studies demonstrate that this does not always correlate with in vivo treatment efficacy (193, 196, 199). Furthermore, a recent study showed that Bartonella spp. can acquire mutations during in vitro testing that confer resistance to certain antibiotics (including rifampin and streptomycin) producing highly resistant phenotypes (201). Thus, the extent of the stress-driven ability to generate resistant clones should be considered when therapy is chosen in clinical cases.

sect2.title: CHOICE AND USE OF ANTIMICROBIALS
sect2.para: Treatment of infections caused byBartonella spp. is challenging, primarily because treatment regimens are based on limited data from case reports, small series, and personal experience. Furthermore, clinical decisions regarding treatment are even more complex due to the observation that in vitro susceptibility testing often does not correlate with a clinical response and therefore is not performed routinely (199, 202, 203). The varying circumstances, disease presentations, clinical status (e.g., immunocompetent versus immunocompromised patients), and outcome dictate different approaches to treatment. The general principles of treatment are discussed here. For more detailed discussions of treatment strategies, see the reviews in references 108, 196, 199, 202, and 203.

Typical CSD is a self-limited illness with only a minimal benefit from antibiotic treatment. Antimicrobials are not indicated in most cases, particularly when spontaneous shrinkage of lymphadenopathy is clearly noted. For patients with extensive lymphadenopathy or persistent systemic symptoms and for immunocompromised patients, azithromycin should be considered (204). Suppurative nodes should be drained by large-bore needle aspiration. For extranodal (atypical) CSD, treatment recommendations depend on the specific syndrome and severity.

Immunocompromised patients withBartonella infection should generally be treated and are candidates for prolonged antibiotic treatment, depending on the clinical syndrome and degree of immunosuppression. Treatment for several months is recommended for patients with bacillary angiomatosis or peliosis hepatis.

The current recommendation for treatment ofBartonella endocarditis is doxycycline for 6 weeks in conjunction with gentamicin for 2 weeks or rifampin for 6 weeks. Some experts recommend prolonging doxycycline to 3 months or more and measuring anti-Bartonella IgG titers every 6 to 8 weeks as a guide to duration of therapy, particularly when the infected valve was not resected.

Due to the high mortality of symptomatic patients with Oroya fever and the high occurrence of secondary infections, combination antibiotic regimens are often recommended. Treatment of verruga peruana is not always required. Patients with numerous lesions, especially lesions present for only a short period, may respond well to antibiotic therapy.

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING
sect2.para: Though not yet standardized, serology is the most used method to support the diagnosis ofBartonella infections in humans, particularly CSD and Bartonella endocarditis. However, both IFA assays and EIA are often difficult to interpret due to the frequent lack of anti-Bartonella IgM, late seroconversion, cross-reactivity between antibodies against B. henselae, B. quintana, and other Bartonella spp., and variable sensitivity depending on test antigens, laboratory cutoffs, and specific procedures (19, 147–150, 152–156). Serology results should be reported with reference to cutoff values for a positive test. If serology results against more than one Bartonella sp., in particular B. henselae and B. quintana, are reported, it is advised to add a comment indicating that serology cannot reliably discriminate between Bartonella spp. Titers of IgG may remain positive for >2 years after disease onset. Although the level of IgG antibodies decreases over time, the rate of the decay is usually too low to allow detection of a significant decrease over intervals of 2 to 3 weeks, as is often recommended for serodiagnosis of infectious diseases (152, 160).

sect1.title: Cat Scratch Disease
sect1.para: CSD can easily be overlooked if the clinician fails to obtain an adequate history of cat exposure. On the other hand, 15 to 20% of CSD patients do not report cat contact, and one must also keep an open mind to the possibility of transmission ofB. henselae from other animals, such as dogs. Laboratory diagnosis of CSD relies mainly on serology. NAATs increase the diagnostic specificity and sensitivity when clinical specimens suitable for PCR are available. Other tests have low sensitivity (culture and Warthin-Starry silver staining), low specificity (cytology and histopathology), or limited availability in routine diagnostic laboratories (Western blotting and immunohistochemistry). When serology is negative, when spontaneous regression of lymph node size does not occur, and particularly when constitutional symptoms persist, malignancy must be ruled out, and lymph node biopsy is indicated.

sect1.title: Trench Fever
sect1.para: Definitive diagnosis of trench fever is made whenB. quintana is isolated from blood cultures; however, due to the low sensitivity of culture isolation, PCR is more often used. Serology is often positive in the acute disease, while patients with chronic bacteremia may be seronegative (33, 205). Patients with high titers of IgG antibodies should be evaluated for endocarditis. In epidemics, trench fever should be differentiated from epidemic louse-borne typhus and relapsing fever, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and Borrelia recurrentis, respectively, which occur under similar conditions and share many clinical features (205).

sect1.title: Carrion’s Disease
sect1.para: B. bacilliformis infection should be suspected in any individual who has visited an area of endemicity and developed systemic febrile illness, severe hemolytic anemia, or cutaneous lesions. Diagnosis of Oroya fever is corroborated by the following. (i) Positive blood cultures are obtained for B. bacilliformis (reported for >70% patients with acute disease). The success rate is much lower when attempting to grow B. bacilliformis from affected lymph nodes or bone marrow (91, 94, 206, 207). (ii) Direct microscopic examination of Giemsa-stained thin blood smears can corroborate the diagnosis (91). (iii) Serologic assays may be helpful, especially in epidemiological studies. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs), IFA tests, indirect hemagglutination tests, and Western blot tests with various degrees of sensitivity have been developed (91, 208–210). (iv) Several PCR assays have been described; however, the role of PCR performed on blood samples remains to be clinically validated. Also, the limited resources in areas of endemicity limit a wide-scale use of molecular methods (211).

Diagnosis of verruga peruana is mostly clinical, based on typical characteristics of skin lesions acquired in an area of endemicity. Skin biopsy demonstrating the characteristic histopathology may be required to confirm the diagnosis. Giemsa staining may show characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions within endothelial cells, referred to as Rocha-Lima inclusions (95, 96, 212). Blood cultures may be positive for B. bacilliformis in patients with verruga peruana; however, this finding is difficult to interpret, since transient or chronic bacteremia has been reported in asymptomatic patients (40).

sect1.title: Bartonella Endocarditis
sect1.para: Due to the poor sensitivity of cultures performed using clinical specimens of human blood or valvular tissue, laboratory diagnosis ofBartonella endocarditis is based mainly on serological assays and PCR. Guidance indicating potential cross reactivity between Bartonella and Coxiella burnetii serology should be noted in the laboratory report. PCR performed on valvular tissue is considered a highly sensitive and specific method for the detection of Bartonella DNA and, when coupled with sequencing, is the most reliable means for identification of the Bartonella spp. or subspecies involved. PCR performed on whole blood or serum specimens is less sensitive (45, 165).

sect1.title: Bacillary Angiomatosis and Bacillary Peliosis
sect1.para: Bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis are diagnosed by histological examination. Warthin-Starry silver staining often reveals clusters of bacilli. Blood cultures as well as direct cultures from involved organs may be positive but are not universally so (169, 213). PCR has identified Bartonella-specific DNA sequences in affected organs (110, 128, 169, 214).
